--- ch07/lesson-01/slide-04.png ---
| The three-tier architecture i

Three-tier architecture is a client-server software architecture pattern in which the
user interface, functional process logic, data storage and data access are developed
and maintained as independent modules

--- ch07/lesson-01/slide-05.png ---
| Data tier G

* Contains the business and operational data

¢ The data is stored in a relational database which is
typically hosted on a machine other than the
application

* Guidewire supports the following Relational
Database Management Systems (RDBMS):
* Oracle Enterprise
« Microsoft SQL Server

* H2 for training and development only

--- ch07/lesson-01/slide-06.png ---
| Application tier

Gi

Contains the functional process and business logic
The application logic is written in Gosu

Guidewire supports the following application
servers:

WebSphere
WebLogic
Apache Tomcat
JBoss EAP

Jetty for training and development only

--- ch07/lesson-01/slide-07.png ---
| Presentation tier i

* Contains the user interface

* Each application generates a collection of standard
HTML pages that are rendered by the browser

¢ Modern web browsers support the Guidewire user
interface

* Chrome
« Firefox

* Microsoft Internet Explorer

* Microsoft Edge

--- ch07/lesson-01/slide-08.png ---

Guidewire application-specific
functionality

--- ch07/lesson-01/slide-20.png ---
| The Guidewire platform fa
¢ The Guidewire platform is a layer of configuration technology that includes the
functionality needed to define a Guidewire application

¢ Itcontains common resources and configuration techniques that are shared by all
Guidewire applications. For example:

* Data model entities, PCF files, and application logic to manage Users
* Data model entities and PCF files to create and assign Activities to other users
¢ This course focuses on the Guidewire platform

Guidewire Platform offers technology for configuring

Application Integration :
Mechanisms :

--- ch07/lesson-01/slide-22.png ---
The Guidewire training
environment

--- ch07/lesson-01/slide-23.png ---
| TrainingApp fa
¢ Developed exclusively for training
rainingApp ; oo.
¢ Designed to function like a contact management
application
* Stores and manages contacts and related information

¢« Examples of each fundamental configuration feature

* Data Model, User Interface, Application Logic, Integration
Mechanisms

* Small number of entities and screens

¢ Excludes complex functionality

Application Integration

Interface Logic Mechanisms

Gradle

* Open source build automation system

* Builds upon the concepts of Apache Ant

¢ Flexible and extendable

« Run tasks from command prompt

* To view available tasks, rungwb tasks ina

| Guidewire Studio G

* Guidewire Studio is an Integrated Developer Environment (IDE) based on IntelliJ
IDEA

* Guidewire Studio comes bundled with your application as an application project
* Supports:

Gosu, XML, JAVA* 2

Refactoring =A

Plugin extensibility =

Dynamic type support

Make, run and debug

Guidewire editors

Built-in version control

familiar with the development environment.

They would like to know how to start/stop Studio and the application.

They want to understand the high level anatomy of Studio and see a brief

| Data Model entities

Gi

¢ Entities are the high-level business objects used by the Guidewire application,

such as ABContact, Policy, Account, Invoice, Claim

¢ Anentity serves as the root object for PCF files, Gosu Rules and other data

related areas

« Anentity defines a set of entity fields to store information. You can add the

following kinds of fields to an entity:

+ Data
+ Column

* Relationship
+ Foreign key
+ Array
+ Type key

| Data fields

Gi

¢ Adata field stores a single value that does not reference any other object or table

¢ Typically defined with the <column> element

¢« Examples of single values:
* Name is a varchar
* CreateTime is a datetime
* PrefersContactByEmail is a bit

* Score is an integer

| Array fields G

« An array defines a set of additional entities of the same type to associate with the
main entity

¢ For example, ABContact entity includes an array of ContactNote entities. This
means ABContact can have zero, one or more ContactNotes associated to it.

within the application. In most cases a typelist is rendered as a drop-down list in the user
interface

- Atypekey field is entity field that is associated with a specific typelist. It can point to exactly
one value in the typelist

--- ch07/lesson-03/slide-04.png ---
| Entity

object entity

¢ An entity is a definition of a business object used by the application, such as
Policy, User, ABContact, Producer, etc.

¢ Entities are defined in entity definition files (ETI) eti
* The ETI file describes the entity in XML format |
¢ There are two main types of entities:

* Base application entities
* Custom entities

--- ch07/lesson-03/slide-05.png ---
| Base application entities Gi

¢ Abase application entity is an entity created by Guidewire and shipped as part of
the out-of-the-box configuration

* Guidewire creates base application entities on the application or the platform level

¢ Application entities are specific to
application

¢ Platform entities are common to all
Guidewire applications

Activity

--- ch07/lesson-03/slide-06.png ---
| Custom entities Gi

eti

¢ Acustom entity is an entity
created by the customer

eti
EI

MedCase Ext LE « Acustom entity can be created

only on the application level and
it will be local inside that
application

--- ch07/lesson-03/slide-07.png ---
| Entity extension G

Base application entities are read-only to prevent any conflicts during upgrade to
the next version of the Guidewire application

The concepts of an Entity extension allows customers to safely add new fields to
base application entities or to override certain attributes of existing base
application entity fields

The entity extension is defined in an ETX file

etx
To keep the maintenance of entities simple a base application entity E|
can have at most one ETX file

For fields that are added to a base application entity, Guidewire recommends that
the field name should end with _Ext

Answer G&G

_~ — Describe some of the differences between the files in the
¢ ..\Metadata\Typelist\ and ..\Extensions\Typelist\ folders.

Files under Metadata are read-only and are specific to the base configuration. You
cannot create Typelist files in the Metadata directory but can create Typelist files in the
Extensions directory. Only internal Typelist extension files (TIX) are in the Metadata
directory. Only external Typelist extension files (TTX) are in the Extensions directory.
Both directories contain Typelist (TT]) files.

,~ — ADetail View that displays data must have at least one root object. Why?

sooo ooo ooo Ooo eo

--- ch07/lesson-06/slide-29.png ---
Answer Gi

,~ — ADetail View that displays data must have at least one root object. Why?

¢
¢
¢

The input widgets of a Detail View must reference some object in order to specify
where the data they display comes from. This object must be the root object, or an
object related to the root object. Therefore, in order to display data, a root object is
needed.

,~ — ADetail View that displays data must have at least one input column.
¢ Why?

¢
¢

sooo ooo ooo Ooo eo

--- ch07/lesson-06/slide-31.png ---
Answer

7
¢
¢
¢

sSoooOo ooo oOo OS oe

A Detail View that displays data must have at least one input column.
Why?

Input columns are used to organize atomic widgets in a Detail View. Every input
widget must be in an input column. If a Detail View displays data, then it has at least
one input widget, which means it must have at least one input column.

Array methods that require logic

« Array methods include
* Getting information about the array
* Getting members of the array that match a given condition
*« Some methods require an argument
« Argument must be an expression of a condition, such as:
¢ Returns true if any row in the array matches the condition
« Returns the first row that matches the condition
* Returns all rows that match the condition

« Argument must be a Gosu block expression

--- ch07/lesson-08/slide-11.png ---
Common array methods (1 of 2)

¢ hasMatch (condition)
* Determine if any element in an array matches a given condition
* Syntax: array. hasMatch (\ name -> conditionToMatch)
* countWhere (condition)

¢ Returns count of elements that match a given condition in an array
¢ Syntax: array.countWhere(\ name -> conditionToMatch)

--- ch07/lesson-08/slide-12.png ---
Common array methods (2 of 2) fa

¢ firstWhere (condition)
¢ Retrieve the first element in an array that matches a given condition
* Syntax: array. firstWhere (\ name -> conditionToMatch)
¢ where (condition)

« Retrieves a target array that consists of all the members of a source array that match a given
condition

¢ Syntax: array.where(\ name -> conditionToMatch)

¢ Ablock is an expression of logic passed to a method as an argument
« Some array methods require conditions using a block
¢ The block consists of four parts:

1. \, which identifies that the following is a block

2. Anelement name representing each element of the array
3. ->, which identifies the start of the condition
4

A condition, which relates to the element

--- ch07/lesson-08/slide-15.png ---
About rational numbers Gi

Rounding large decimal numbers is often required when numbers scale to infinity
(i.e. 1/3 = 0.3333333333...), however, the rounding will produce data errors over
time as the numbers are used in other calculations (data loss)

gw.util.Rational has an infinite scale which allows you to preserve whatever
value is placed in it

gw.util.money and gw.util.science store numbers as Rationals. This means
using and testing data with those libraries becomes easier and more accurate

Arithmetic operators can be applied to rational numbers using the following syntax:
Rational.add(i)

Rational.subtract(i)

Rational.multiply(i)

Rational.divide(i)

Question G

_- — Whatis the difference between an "execute all" rule set and an “exit after
Yo first action" rule set?

Sooo ODDODSDoDoOoOoDOoOoOoOSD

--- ch07/lesson-09/slide-31.png ---
Answer a

_— — Whatis the difference between an "execute all" rule set and an “exit after
a first action" rule set?
? In an “execute all" rule set, all rules are executed. For example, validation rule sets are
execute all. All validation conditions are checked, regardless of how many are true. In
an "exit after first action" rule set, you do not typically execute all rules. When the first
true condition is found, the action associated with that condition is taken and the rule
set is exited. For example, assignment rule sets are exit after first action. Once an

assignment is made, the rule set exits so that later code doesn't reassign the object.

SOOO ODDDSDoOODDODOoOoS

Gosu enhancements

--- ch07/lesson-10/slide-04.png ---
I Gosu enhancements Gi

* Gosu enhancements allow you to augment classes and other types with additional
concrete methods and properties

¢ The most valuable and useful uses of this feature are:

* to add new properties and methods to Guidewire Entities. Entities are defined in XML files and
source code is automatically generated, thus cannot be modified, and

* to define additional utility methods on a Java class or interface that cannot be directly

modified. For example, the source code is unavailable, or a given class is final (cannot be
subclassed)

¢ [fan Entity/Java class is enhanced, then all the subtypes/subclasses will
automatically inherit all elements from the enhancement

©

--- ch07/lesson-10/slide-05.png ---
I Enhancement components

Gi

¢ Calculate derived

values

Ce

¢ Take input parameters,

and/or

Ce

Set field values that
require additional logic

Modify other objects,
and/or

Create objects

ms

--- ch07/lesson-10/slide-06.png ---
I Derived (virtual) properties Gi

ABPersonEnhancement.gsx enhances ABPerson entity and defines the Age getter
property

* Property calculates age based on the date of birth value

Derived values should NOT be stored in the database, because storing them
would be redundant

* They are calculated from physical fields

--- ch07/lesson-10/slide-07.png ---
I Getter property

¢ Agetter property is used to calculate a derived value
* Property not declared at Data Model level
* Asa result the value is not stored in database
* Code cannot receive input parameters
* Code can only return a value and should not alter any data
* Null safe
¢« Example: ABPerson.Age
* Derives value by calculating number of years between date of birth and current date
« Returns "Unknown" if date of birth is null

* Storing Age in database is redundant

--- ch07/lesson-10/slide-08.png ---
I Setter property Gi

¢ Asetter property takes a single input value and uses it to modify the
associated object

« Property not declared at data model level
« Value given to setter may or may not be stored in database
« Value manipulated by setter is typically stored in database
* Code must receive exactly one input parameter
* Should not be used to alter other objects
* Example: ABPolicyPerson.HeightInInches (arg)

* Getter takes height from database (in meters) and converts it to inches (so, for example, it can
be displayed in Ul)

* Setter takes height (in inches) and converts it to meters before saving it to database

--- ch07/lesson-10/slide-09.png ---
I Function

¢ A function is a set of statements that executes a logical unit of work
* Can receive any number of parameters
* Can optionally return a value
* Create when your code...
+ Requires multiple input parameters, and/or
* Modifies multiple unrelated fields on given object, and/or
* Creates or modifies other objects, and/or
* Does not "feel like" a setter
¢« Example: ABPerson.assignDefaultOccupation ()
+ ABPersonEnhancement.gsx enhances ABPerson entity

« Uses information known about object to generate default occupation

--- ch07/lesson-10/slide-10.png ---
I User stories Gi

¢« Enhancements - User Story#1: “For each person, if the Age is not Unknown, we
want to see how many years the person has remaining until retirement. This value
should be calculated from the Age and be displayed as a read-only field in the UI
right under the Date of Birth field on the Person Info card.”

¢ Enhancements — User Story#2: “We also need a Toolbar button on the Person
Info card with the label: ‘Suggest insight score’. This button should be available
only if the location is in edit mode and the contact’s Score field is null. When the
user clicks on it a function should be executed with the following logic:
« Ifthe Employment Info section is filled out completely the Score should be set to 10

« Ifthe Employment Info and License Info sections are both filled out completely, the Score
should be set to 20.

* Otherwise nothing happens.”

Answer Gi

,~ — What type of logic does a getter implement? A setter? A method?

¢
¢
¢

The correct responses are:

Getter: Logic that returns a derived value and does not take parameters or change
other data.

Setter: Logic that takes a single input value and uses that to modify some other field or
set of fields on the given object.

Method: Logic that requires parameters, changes data, or otherwise does more than
simply deriving or setting a value.

Review before the demo: PCF methods G&G

¢ APCF method is a plain old Gosu function that is local in a PCF file
* ...iS local (private) in the PCF file that defines it (not even referenced files can access it)

* ...cannot be debugged at the place of definition (you have to open the generated
<PCFFileName>Expressions.gs file after code generation, locate the method and put a
breakpoint there)

* ...is called from a widget property (e.g.: action, value, available, editable, etc.)

* PCF methods are defined on the Code tab of the main PCF Element — container
or location — and have direct access to the root object(s)

¢ The logic the function implements is typically tied to one or more widgets in that
PCF file, and it is not needed anywhere else. For example:

* determining the label (View or View/Edit) for a button
* determining if a TextInput widget is editable or not editable
* executing some initialization logic after navigating to a location

¢ Verifies that the user entered the data in the correct format for that field
¢ E.g.: tax id must be a nine-digit number with hyphens after the third and fifth digits
* Prevents the user from saving invalid business data

* Could be implemented in the data model or the UI tier

i Business logic — validation rules Gi

¢ Validation rules are written as Gosu rules and contain logic to validate (complex)
logical conditions and/or relationships between entity fields

¢ E.g.: primary phone number must be selected if the user has more than one phone numbers
« Validation rules can be used to:

* Ensure that the user enters data that makes sense

« Ensure that the user enters all necessary data

« Manage relationships between data fields

--- ch07/lesson-17/slide-18.png ---
i Business logic — validation rules

« Business rules can show warnings or errors
¢ Validation during saved

* Checked when Validatable entity is committed to the database
¢ Entity must implement the Validatable delegate

* implementsEntity tag in the ETI/ETX file

--- ch07/lesson-17/slide-19.png ---
i Delegates Gi

« Adelegate models a capability and allows sharing functionality across the data
model

¢« Examples:
« Any entity implementing the Validatable delegate can be validated by Gosu rules

« Any entity implementing the Assignable delegate can be automatically assigned to a user and
user group by Gosu rules

¢ Technically a delegate is a virtual object defined in the data model
« It consists of database fields and/or methods that can be reused by multiple entities
« Anentity can implement multiple delegates

--- ch07/lesson-17/slide-20.png ---
i Delegate examples Gi

¢ Validatable delegate defines reusable functions to show warning or error
messages

¢ Assignable delegate contains functions to perform the assignment and database
fields to store the assignment details (AssignedUser, AssignedTime)

--- ch07/lesson-17/slide-21.png ---
i Validation graph

¢ The rules engine performs validation during database commit
¢ Validation is triggered when:
¢ Validatable object is created or changed

¢ Validatable sub-object is created, changed, or removed

* "triggersValidation" attribute on the foreign key or array controls this behavior

--- ch07/lesson-17/slide-22.png ---
i Validation graph

¢ The rules engine performs validation during database commit
¢ Validation is triggered when:
¢ Validatable object is created or changed

¢ Validatable sub-object is created, changed, or removed

* "triggersValidation" attribute on the foreign key or array controls this behavior

for a single field relationships between entity fields
¢ Implemented in the UI and must be ¢ Entity must implement the
configured per widget Validatable delegate in the data
model

¢ Application enforces compliance in
the UI and through the APIs

Question G

_— — Describe at least one limitation of relying heavily on subtype hierarchies.

4
¢
¢

ee ee a

--- ch07/lesson-20/slide-20.png ---
Answer fa

_— — Describe at least one limitation of relying heavily on subtype hierarchies.
4

¢
¢

One major limitation of a subtype hierarchy is that a subtype entity can only have one
parent entity and multiple inheritance (two or more direct parents) is not supported. In
addition, the subtype always inherits the parents elements, meaning the subtype
contains the parent fields.

For a deep hierarchy (many levels), this means the lowest child will inherit all the fields
of the parents. Deep subtype hierarchies can result in very wide tables that are highly
denormalized resulting in poor application performance.

- SSS SSS SE See

proctored exam?
¢ The exam will consist of multiple-choice questions.
¢ The questions are meant to determine your ability to apply your knowledge.

* The exam will be proctored online by our proctoring partner using your webcam
and audio (no headphones allowed).

« Examinees will be asked to show identification.
*« The exam must be completed within 3 hours from the start, in one sitting.

« The proctored exam should take approximately 2-3 hours to complete.

* On average, learners spend 6 to 8 hours completing the exam.

Fundamentals exam.

« Learners are allowed to pause and restart their open-book exam multiple times

| How you should prepare for a Knowledge Check

* Knowledge Checks test your knowledge of a lesson or a course.
* Knowledge Checks are like small quizzes.
* Complete the lessons in the relevant course:

* Course content

* Demonstrations

« Hands-on lab exercises

--- ch07/lesson-23/slide-16.png ---
| What to expect during the Knowledge Check Gi

¢« Knowledge Checks will consist of 5-20 multiple-choice questions.

* Questions may be answered using the content from the lesson (open-book).

¢ Learners, on average, spend 10 to 30 minutes to complete the knowledge check.
* You must pass the Knowledge Check to complete the lesson or the course.

* You can retake the Knowledge Check as many times as you like.
